question: Question_01_(c)
statement:
Evaluate the following limit.

\begin{align*}\lim_{x \to \infty} \left( e^{-x} - x \right)\end{align*}
sols:
We will consider the function inside the limit as the sum of two
functions\begin{align*}e^{-x}\end{align*} and $-x$. If we take their limits separately, we
get:

$\displaystyle \lim_{x \to \infty} e^{-x} = 0$

$\displaystyle \lim_{x \to \infty} -x$ diverges to
$\displaystyle -\infty$

We can see that as \emph{x} goes to infinity, the $e^{-x}$ term is
decreasing towards zero and the $-x$ term grows larger and larger. So,
as \emph{x} goes to infinity the combined value of $e^{-x} - x$ will
grow more and more negative. Thus we have:

$\displaystyle \lim_{x \to \infty} e^{-x} - x$ diverges to
$\displaystyle -\infty$
hints:
What does the graph of $e^{-x}$ look like? What happens to it as
\emph{x} goes to infinity?
